cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive basic course in spoken and written French for students who have absolutely no prior knowledge of French: comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary French I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: No previous knowledge of French.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL102H1, FSL120H1, FSL121Y1, FSL122H1, FSL 200+ level courses

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

NOTE: This course is reserved for students with NO previous knowledge of French. Such students are prohibited from completing the online placement test without receiving special Department permission. If you have any prior experience in French (including middle or high school French), you are NOT eligible to enrol in this course. You must instead take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test. If you have studied French at any time in the past, you will not receive credit for FSL100H1 unless you obtain special permission from the Department under exceptional circumstances.

notes.name: Course Note

Timetable Instructions

NOTE: If you have not completed FSL100H1, you must take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test prior to enrolling in this course. If the test results indicate that you must take a level other than FSL102H1, you will not receive credit for this course.

cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL120H1, FSL121Y1, FSL122H1, FSL 200+ level courses, placement in FSL120H1, FSL122H1, FSL200+ level courses based on the results of the French Placement Test

notes.name: Course Note

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a FRE language course for the first time MUST complete the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a FRE language course for the first time MUST complete the French Placement Test.

cmCourseInfo.description: The objective of this course, which serves as a starting point in our series of FSL courses, is to introduce students to the phonetic system of the French language, to teach basic vocabulary and to develop awareness of the functions of language in different situations and contexts. An awareness of various francophone cultures and communities will be developed. All students are REQUIRED to complete the French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/) before enrolling in ANY FSL or FRE language course for the FIRST time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Functional French-Novice
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: All students are REQUIRED to complete the French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/) before enrolling in ANY FSL or FRE language course for the FIRST time.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL100H1. Not open to students who have previously studied French and not open to native speakers of French.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
• Student enrol in LEC0101 must enrol in PRA0101
  • Student enrol in LEC0201 must enrol in PRA0201

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a FSL language course for the first time MUST complete the French Placement Test.

An awareness of various francophone cultures and communities will be developed. All students are REQUIRED to complete the French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/) before enrolling in ANY FSL or FRE language course for the FIRST time.

cmCourseInfo.description: Through the use of teaching materials adapted to their level, students will continue to develop their linguistics abilities and to use them in specific situations. For instance, students will learn how to ask for information, how to refuse or accept an offer. On completion of this course, a linguistic system of basic but useful structures will have been assimilated. An awareness of various francophone cultures and communities will be developed. All students are REQUIRED to complete the French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/) before enrolling in ANY FSL or FRE language course for the FIRST time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Functional French-Advanced Beginner
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL105H5 or the equivalent as determined by the department's Placement Test.  Before enrolling in a French language course for the first time all students MUST complete the Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/).
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL102H1. Grade 11 and Grade 12 Core French and all grade levels in French Immersion, Extended French, and French Secondary Schools.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
• Student enrol in LEC0101 must enrol in PRA0101
  • Student enrol in LEC0201 must enrol in PRA0201

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended for students having some knowledge of French but wishing to increase their proficiency in written and spoken French comprehension and production. Students also gain an introduction to a variety of French-speaking cultures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary French III
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL102H1 or placement in FSL120H1 based on the results of the French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL121Y1, FSL122H1, FSL 200+ level courses, placement in FSL122H1 or FSL200+ level courses based on the results of the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Note: Programs requiring FSL121Y1 (no longer offered) will accept the combination of FSL120H1 and FSL122H1 as its equivalent.

If you have not completed FSL102H1, you must take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test prior to enrolling in this course. If the test results indicate that you must take a level other than FSL120H1, you will not receive credit for this course.

This is a 4-hour course (3-hr lecture, 1-hr asynchronous activities).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended for students having some knowledge of French but wishing to further increase their proficiency in written and spoken French comprehension and production. The focus will be on developing greater autonomy and exploring a variety of French-speaking cultures.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL120H1 or placement in FSL122H1 based on the results of the French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL121Y1, FSL 200+ level courses, placement in FSL200+ level courses based on the results of the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a FSL language course for the first time MUST complete the French Placement Test.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on developing communication skills as well as furthering students’ fluency through the production and understanding of authentic messages, working on engaging tasks while using more diverse lexical forms and expressions. Students will participate in interpersonal interactions where they learn to express emotion and opinion using culturally appropriate expressions and greater vocabulary breadth. An awareness of various francophone cultures and communities will be developed. All students are REQUIRED to complete the French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/) before enrolling in ANY FSL or FRE language course for the FIRST time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Functional French – Low Intermediate I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL106H5 or the equivalent as determined by the department's French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/)
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL205Y5 or FSL121Y1 or FSL120H1 or FSL122H1 or higher level FSL course. Grade 12 Core French, and all high school grade levels in French Immersion, Extended French, and French Secondary Schools.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a FSL language course for the first time MUST complete the French Placement Test.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on nuancing acquired written and oral communication skills and on further developing students’ fluency and accuracy through the production and understanding of complex sentences, refined forms and idiomatic expressions, and the further development of discourse-oriented abilities to create meaning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Functional French - Low Intermediate II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL205H5 or the equivalent as determined by the department's French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL205Y5 or FSL121Y1 or FSL122H1 or higher level FSL course. Grade 12 Core French, and all high school grade levels in French Immersion, Extended French, and French Secondary Schools.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides students with the opportunity to become proficient, focused, autonomous French language learners. The course’s main objective is to provide a communicative learning environment through activities structured around real-world, everyday contexts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate French I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL121Y1/FSL122H1 or placement in FSL220H1 based on the results of the French Placement Test. Students who are fluent French speakers, whose command of the French language is equivalent to near-native proficiency are not permitted to take take this course.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL221Y1, FSL222H1, FSL224H1, FSL225H1, FSL226H1, FSL271H1, FSL300+ level courses, placement in FSL222H1 or higher based on the results of the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Note: Programs requiring FSL221Y1 (no longer offered) will accept the combination of FSL220H1 and FSL222H1 as its equivalent.

If you have not completed FSL122H1, you must take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test prior to enrolling in this course. If the test results indicate that you must take a level other than FSL220H1, you will not receive credit for this course.

This is a 4-hour course (3-hr lecture, 1-hr asynchronous activities).

Students who are fluent French speakers, whose command of the French language is equivalent to near-native proficiency are not permitted to take this course.

cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL221Y1, FSL271H1, FSL 300+ level courses, any FRE course, placement in FSL300+ level courses based on the results of the French Placement Test.

subjectPost.name: French Language and French Linguistics Major
French Language and French Linguistics Specialist

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to present students with the practical skills, grammatical knowledge and metalinguistic awareness needed to engage with introductory French linguistics courses. Students will hone higher-order analytical skills related to French language and linguistics through comprehension and production exercises and activities. A variety of textual excerpts selected from several subfields of linguistics will allow exposure to the basic elements of French linguistics through which students will develop awareness and comfort with academic writing and academic discourse in French. Emphasis is on the appropriate use of formal registers, terminology, incorporation of logical connectors and analytical thinking in written and spoken French.
cmCourseInfo.title: Practical French for Exploring Linguistics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL220H1. Students may also fulfill this prerequisite requirement based on the results of their French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL225H1, FSL312H1, FSL313H1, FSL314H1, FSL315H1, FSL322H1, FSL375Y1, FSL375H1, FSL 400-level courses.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

NOTE:  If this is your first French course at U of T St. George, you must take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test prior to enrolling in this course. You are only eligible for this course if the test results indicate that you must take FSL222H1 or FSL320H1. If the test results indicate that you must take any level other than FSL222H1 or FSL320H1, you will not receive credit for this course.

This is a 3-hour course (2-hr lecture, 1-hr asynchronous activities).

subjectPost.name: French Language and French Linguistics Major
French Language and French Linguistics Specialist

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to present students with the practical skills, grammatical knowledge and metalinguistic awareness needed to engage with introductory French literature courses. Students will hone higher-order analytical skills related to French language and literature through comprehension and production exercises and activities. A variety of textual excerpts selected from geographically diverse essays, poetry and novels will allow exposure to the basic elements of French literary analysis through which students will develop awareness and comfort with academic writing and academic discourse in French. Emphasis is on the appropriate use of formal registers, terminology, incorporation of logical connectors and analytical thinking in written and spoken French.
cmCourseInfo.title: Practical French for Exploring Literature
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL220H1. Students may also fulfill this prerequisite requirement based on the results of their French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL224H1, FSL312H1, FSL313H1, FSL314H1, FSL315H1, FSL322H1, FSL375Y1, FSL375H1, FSL 400-level courses.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

NOTE:  If this is your first French course at U of T St. George, you must take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test prior to enrolling in this course. You are only eligible for this course if the test results indicate that you must take FSL222H1 or FSL320H1. If the test results indicate that you must take any level other than FSL222H1 or FSL320H1, you will not receive credit for this course.

This is a 3-hour course (2-hr lecture, 1-hr asynchronous activities).

courses.name: Strategies for Autonomous Learning in French as a Second Language

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides French language learners with an understanding of how one best acquires French as a second or third language including various FSL strategies that allow for effective, autonomous learning. It further implements a structure to encourage continuous active reflection and self-assessment. Students will first learn about the types of knowledge and sub-skills that must be acquired to master French including vocabulary and grammar. Language benchmarks and self-evaluation tools are then introduced to help learners to profile their four main competences (reading, writing, listening, and speaking). Subsequently, they will receive practical training in the use of specific online resources (e.g., Bon Patron) geared towards improving French writing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Strategies for Autonomous Learning in French as a Second Language
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1/ FSL222H1
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: FSL321Y1/FSL320H1/FSL322H1, as determined by the French Placement Test
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FRE226H1, FRE225Y1/JFI225Y1, FSL375H1, FSL375Y1, FSL 400-level courses

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The placement test https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test  is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a FSL language course for the first time MUST complete the French Placement Test.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on understanding information, comparing and reformulating types of discourse, developing more refined fluency and spontaneity in proficiently discussing current and cultural affairs and contentious topics, using different registers and tone in a broad range of situations and texts & media encountered in their academic experiences. Understanding various francophone cultures and communities will be part of the course discussion. All students are REQUIRED to complete the French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/) before enrolling in ANY FSL or FRE language course for the FIRST time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Functional French - High Intermediate I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL206H5 or the equivalent as determined by the department’s French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/).
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FRE180H5 or FRE181H5 or FSL305Y5 or FSL220H1 or FSL222H1 or FSL22Y1 or higher level FSL course, all high school grade levels in French Immersion, Extended French, and French Secondary Schools.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in an FSL language course for the first time MUST complete the French Placement Test.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on analyzing and synthesizing information, comparing and evaluating diverse types of discourse, developing advanced fluency and spontaneity, accuracy and complexity in proficiently discussing and writing about current and cultural topics, using different registers and tone in a broad range of situations, texts & media. Understanding various francophone cultures and communities will be integrated in the course content and student learning experience. All students are REQUIRED to complete the French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/) before enrolling in ANY FSL or FRE language course for the FIRST time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Functional French – High Intermediate II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL305H5 or the equivalent as determined by the department's French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/).
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FRE180H5 or FRE181H5 or FSL305Y5 or FSL221Y1 or FSL222H1 or higher level FSL course, all high school grade levels in French Immersion, Extended French, and French Secondary Schools.

subjectPost.name: French Language and French Linguistics Major
French Language and French Linguistics Specialist

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended for students who have already mastered the basic competences in French language proficiency. The materials used in this course adopt an active approach which puts emphasis on the student being at the centre of the learning process. Students will solidify writing, and speaking skills as well as understanding of written and spoken French through exploration of a variety of cultures and viewpoints.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate French III
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1/ FSL222H1 or placement in FSL320H1 based on the results of the French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL321Y1, FSL322H1, FSL375Y1, FSL375H1, FSL 400-level courses. Placement in FSL322H1 or higher based on the results of the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Note: Programs requiring FSL321Y1 (no longer offered) will accept the combination of FSL320H1 and FSL322H1 as its equivalent.

If you have not completed FSL222H1, you must take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test prior to enrolling in this course. If the test results indicate that you must take a level other than FSL320H1, you will not receive credit for this course. Please note that if you took the test prior to June 15, 2023, you may be eligible to take a higher-level class if placed in FSL320. Please contact the Department for more information.

subjectPost.name: French Language and French Linguistics Major
French Language and French Linguistics Specialist

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended as a transition from intermediate- to advanced-level French language proficiency. The materials used in this course adopt an active approach which puts emphasis on the student being at the centre of the learning process. Students will solidify writing, and speaking skills as well as understanding of written and spoken French of various registers through exploration of a variety of cultures and viewpoints.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate French IV
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL320H1 or placement in FSL322H1 based on the results of the French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL321Y1, FSL375Y1, FSL375H1, any FSL 400-level course, placement at the FSL400+ level based on the results of the French Placement Test. May not be taken concurrently with FSL312H1, FSL313H1, FSL314H1, FSL315H1.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Note: Programs requiring FSL321Y1 (no longer offered) will accept the combination of FSL320H1 and FSL322H1 as its equivalent.

If you have not completed FSL320H1, you must take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test prior to enrolling in this course. If the test results indicate that you must take a level other than FSL322H1, you will not receive credit for this course. Please note that if you took the test prior to June 15, 2023, you may be eligible to take a higher-level class if placed in FSL320. Please contact the Department for more information.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This introduction to translation, is designed to improve students’ mastery of French stylistics through English to French and French to English translations. Emphasis is on the practice of translation of a variety of texts and documents with an introduction to the practice of oral interpretation from one language to the other.
cmCourseInfo.title: Practical Translation: French - English
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 1.0 credit in FSL at the 300-level or placement in FSL420H1 based on the results of the French Placement Test
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL375Y1, FSL415H1, FSL442H1, FSL443H1, FSL472H1, FSL473H1, FSL475H1. Students who are fluent French speakers or whose command of the French language is equivalent to near-native proficiency must contact the Department of French before enrolling in this course.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

If you have not taken an FSL course at the UofT St. George campus, you must take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test prior to enrolling in this course. You are eligible for this course if the test results indicate that you must take FSL420H1. If any other level is indicated, you will need special Department permission to take this course. Please note that if you took the test prior June 15, 2023, you may be eligible to take this course if placed in FSL322. Please contact the Department for more information.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in an FSL language course for the first time MUST complete the French Placement Test.

cmCourseInfo.description: Course will focus on developing both oral and written skills in the production and understanding of complex discourse (including organization, cohesion, nuanced lexical forms and expressions) in order to participate in varied, sustained and unscripted situations. An awareness of various francophone cultures and communities will be developed. All students are REQUIRED to complete the French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca) before enrolling in ANY FSL or FRE language course for the FIRST time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Functional French-Advanced I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL306H5 or as determined by the department's Placement Test. All students are REQUIRED to complete the French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/) before enrolling in ANY FSL or FRE language course for the FIRST time.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FRE280Y5 or FRE282H5 or FRE283H5 or FRE382H5 or FRE383H5 or FSL321Y1 or FSL320H1 or FSL322H1. Not open to francophones and/or holders of the French baccalauréat but contingent on the results of the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in an FSL language course for the first time MUST complete the French Placement Test.

cmCourseInfo.description: Students will focus on developing both oral and written skills in the production and understanding of complex discourse (including organization, cohesion, nuanced lexical forms and expressions) in order to initiate and sustain varied and unscripted exchanges. An awareness of various francophone cultures and communities will be developed. All students are REQUIRED to complete the French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca) before enrolling in ANY FSL or FRE language course for the FIRST time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Functional French-Advanced II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL405H5 or the equivalent as determined by the department's French Placement Test. All students are REQUIRED to complete the French Placement Test (https://frenchpt.utm.utoronto.ca/) before enrolling in ANY FSL or FRE language course for the FIRST time.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FRE280Y5 or FRE282H5 or FRE283H5 or FRE382H5 or FRE383H5 or FSL321Y1 or FSL322H. Not open to francophones or holders of the French baccalaureat but contingent on the results of the Placement Test.

subjectPost.name: French as a Second Language Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to strengthen oral and written communication skills in French and develop intercultural competence for a variety of career paths including public relations, international development, federal and provincial government. Students will gain expertise in spoken and written French through in-class activities supported by multimedia.
cmCourseInfo.title: Business French
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL321Y1/ FSL322H1/ FSL315H1. Students may also fulfill this prerequisite requirement based on the results of their French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Students who are fluent French speakers or whose command of the French language is equivalent to near-native proficiency must contact the Department of French before enrolling in this course.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

If you have not taken an FSL course at the UofT St. George campus, you must take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test prior to enrolling in this course. You are eligible for this course if the test results indicate that you must take FSL420H1 or higher. If any other level is indicated, you will need special Department permission to take this course. Please note that if you took the test prior to June 15, 2023 and were placed in FSL322, you may be eligible to take this course. Please contact the Department for more information.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This advanced course in French aims to provide students with a broader understanding and appreciation of French and Francophone culture through the reading and discussion of a variety of texts and multimedia materials. Emphasis is placed on mastery of language skills such as reading comprehension and vocabulary, oral and written communication.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced French I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL321Y1/ FSL322H1 or placement in FSL420H1 based on the results of the French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL421Y1, FSL442H1, FSL443H1, FSL472H1. Students who are fluent French speakers or whose command of the French language is equivalent to near-native proficiency must contact the Department of French before enrolling in this course.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Note: Programs requiring FSL421Y1 (no longer offered) will accept as its equivalent the combination of FSL420H1 and a FRE course.

If you have not completed FSL322H1, you must take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test prior to enrolling in this course. If the test results indicate that you must take a level other than FSL420H1, you will not receive credit for this course.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed for students who wish to consolidate and perfect their writing abilities. Skills developed include the mastery of register-based differences; use of rhetorical and stylistic techniques and systematic self-correction.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Written French II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL421Y1/FSL420H1. Students may also fulfill this prerequisite requirement based on the results of their French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Students who are fluent French speakers or whose command of the French language is equivalent to near-native proficiency must contact the Department of French before enrolling in this course.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

If you have not completed FSL420H1, you must take the French Placement Test at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/placement-test prior to enrolling in this course. If the test results indicate that you must take a level other than FSL442H1, you will not receive credit for this course.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed for students who wish to consolidate and perfect their oral (speaking and listening) abilities. Oral production and improvement of pronunciation will be practiced through reading exercises, presentations, debates, and discussions focusing on a rich vocabulary and contextually appropriate speech registers. Training in the comprehension of spoken French will aim at the development of students’ listening skills through the study of recordings related to various situations and topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Oral French II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL421Y1/ FSL420H1/ FSL375Y1/ (FSL375H1, 0.5 credit in FRE at the 200-level). Students may also fulfill this prerequisite requirement based on the results of their French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL473H1. Students who are fluent French speakers or whose command of the French language is equivalent to near-native proficiency must contact the Department of French before enrolling in this course.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed for students who wish to consolidate and perfect their oral (speaking and listening) abilities. Oral production and improvement of pronunciation will be practiced through reading exercises, presentations, debates, and discussions focusing on a rich vocabulary and contextually appropriate speech registers. Training in the comprehension of spoken French will aim at the development of students’ listening skills through the study of recordings related to various situations and topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Oral French II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL421Y1/ FSL420H1/ FSL375Y1/ (FSL375H1, 0.5 credit in FRE at the 200-level). Students may also fulfill this prerequisite requirement based on the results of their French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL473H1. Students who are fluent French speakers or whose command of the French language is equivalent to near-native proficiency must contact the Department of French before enrolling in this course.

courses.name: Sights, Sounds, and Tastes of the Francophone World

cmCourseInfo.description: This course invites students to explore sights, sounds, and tastes of the French-speaking world, including cuisine, cinema, arts, media, music, comics, and literature. Students will expand their oral and written French language skills to enjoy, share their understanding of, and reflect on Francophone cultural products, practices, and perspectives including through comparisons with students’ home cultures. This course may include an experiential learning component some semesters, with opportunities for field experiences (e.g., restaurants, performances) to discover Francophone sights, sounds, and tastes. When these field experiences are offered, additional costs and application processes may apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sights, Sounds, and Tastes of the Francophone World

cmCourseInfo.description: Do you like creative writing? Are you simply curious about it? Do you want to hone your writing skills in French and develop your creative voice in the process? Then this course is for you. Part workshop in which constructive and supportive feedback will help you develop your writing in French and your creativity, part literary discussion on various aspects of literary technique such as character, setting, plot, point of view, structure or revision (through reading).
cmCourseInfo.title: Creative Writing in French
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL375Y1/ FSL375H1/ FSL421Y1/ FSL420H1
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Students who are fluent French speakers or whose command of the French language is equivalent to near-native proficiency must contact the Department of French before enrolling in this course.
